title: How to Make Poutine

steps.headline: Prepare the potatoes.
steps.description: Cut the potatoes so they are each about 1/3 - 1/4 inch thick. Put them in a large bowl filled with cold water and refrigerate them for about 2 hours.

steps.headline: Heat the butter.
steps.description: Place 4 tbsp. of unsalted butter in a saucepan and heat it up over medium-high heat.

steps.headline: Add the flour to the butter.
steps.description: Add 1/4 cup of flour into the butter and stir it until it is smooth. This should take about 2 minutes.

steps.headline: Add the garlic and shallot.
steps.description: Add one minced clove of garlic and one minced shallot to the mixture and cook them until they are soft, for another 2 or so minutes.

steps.headline: Add the stock, ketchup, Worcestershire sauce, peppercorns, and salt and pepper to the mixture.
steps.description: Add 4 cups of beef stock, 2 tbsp. of ketchup, ½ tsp. Worcestershire sauce, 1 tbsp. peppercorns, and salt and pepper to taste to the mixture. Stir the ingredients together until they have thickened a bit, which should take about 5-6 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove from heat and set aside.
steps.description: You have made the gravy that you will pour over the potatoes.

steps.headline: Cook the potatoes.
steps.description: Drain the potatoes and dry them with paper towels before you fry them. Pour canola oil into a pan and heat it up over medium-high heat. Then, place the potatoes in the pan and stir them to get them in the oil evenly, until they are golden brown and fully cooked.

steps.headline: Drain the potatoes and let them cool.
steps.description: Place the potatoes on paper towels to drain the excess oil and then have them cool for about 20 minutes.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: Place the potatoes on a plate and pour the gravy over them, topping it with 2 cups of cheese curd. Enjoy this dish as a main course while it's nice and hot.

steps.headline: Cook the white onion in butter until it is transparent.
steps.description: Thinly dice 1 white onion and then cook it in 2 tbsp. of butter, stirring lightly until it's transparent. This should take about 3-4 minutes, depending on the size of the onion.

steps.headline: Add the garlic and onion powder, flour, and cornstarch.
steps.description: Add 1 tsp. of garlic powder, 1 tsp. of onion powder, 2 tbsp. of flour, and 2 tsp. of cornstarch to the onion mixture. Continue to stir the ingredients together until they have absorbed all of the butter. This should take another minute or so.

steps.headline: Add the soy sauce and vegetable broth to the mixture.
steps.description: Stir the ingredients together and let everything simmer for about 10 minutes. Add a little more butter or broth if the mixture becomes too solid.

steps.headline: Set the mixture aside.
steps.description: If you'd like it to be extra smooth, you can put the ingredients in an immersion blender and purée them, but this is not necessary.

steps.headline: Prepare the potatoes.
steps.description: Peel and cut 6 white Idaho potatoes into long, thin strings that are each about ⁄3 inch (0.8 cm) thick. Rinse the potatoes a bit after you cut them to cut down on the starchiness. To soften up the potatoes, you can boil a pot of water and blanch them for 4 minutes first, but this is not necessary. If you can handle it, of course, you can prepare the gravy at the same time as you prepare the potatoes. You just have to be very vigilant.

steps.headline: Heat the oil.
steps.description: Pour the vegetable oil onto a saucepan and heat it up under medium high heat. Then, add the cut potatoes and cook them until they are golden brown.

steps.headline: Add the gravy to the potatoes.
steps.description: Place the cooked potatoes on a paper towel to drain some of the oil and then add the gravy and one bag of cheese curds.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: Enjoy this dish on its own while it's hot.

text: Regular Poutine Prepare the potatoes. Cut the potatoes so they are each about 1/3 - 1/4 inch thick. Put them in a large bowl filled with cold water and refrigerate them for about 2 hours. Heat the butter. Place 4 tbsp. of unsalted butter in a saucepan and heat it up over medium-high heat. Add the flour to the butter. Add 1/4 cup of flour into the butter and stir it until it is smooth. This should take about 2 minutes. Add the garlic and shallot. Add one minced clove of garlic and one minced shallot to the mixture and cook them until they are soft, for another 2 or so minutes. Add the stock, ketchup, Worcestershire sauce, peppercorns, and salt and pepper to the mixture. Add 4 cups of beef stock, 2 tbsp. of ketchup, ½ tsp. Worcestershire sauce, 1 tbsp. peppercorns, and salt and pepper to taste to the mixture. Stir the ingredients together until they have thickened a bit, which should take about 5-6 minutes. Remove from heat and set aside. You have made the gravy that you will pour over the potatoes. Cook the potatoes. Drain the potatoes and dry them with paper towels before you fry them. Pour canola oil into a pan and heat it up over medium-high heat. Then, place the potatoes in the pan and stir them to get them in the oil evenly, until they are golden brown and fully cooked. Drain the potatoes and let them cool. Place the potatoes on paper towels to drain the excess oil and then have them cool for about 20 minutes. Serve. Place the potatoes on a plate and pour the gravy over them, topping it with 2 cups of cheese curd. Enjoy this dish as a main course while it's nice and hot. Vegetarian Poutine Cook the white onion in butter until it is transparent. Thinly dice 1 white onion and then cook it in 2 tbsp. of butter, stirring lightly until it's transparent. This should take about 3-4 minutes, depending on the size of the onion. Add the garlic and onion powder, flour, and cornstarch. Add 1 tsp. of garlic powder, 1 tsp. of onion powder, 2 tbsp. of flour, and 2 tsp. of cornstarch to the onion mixture. Continue to stir the ingredients together until they have absorbed all of the butter. This should take another minute or so. Add the soy sauce and vegetable broth to the mixture. Stir the ingredients together and let everything simmer for about 10 minutes. Add a little more butter or broth if the mixture becomes too solid. Set the mixture aside. If you'd like it to be extra smooth, you can put the ingredients in an immersion blender and purée them, but this is not necessary. Prepare the potatoes. Peel and cut 6 white Idaho potatoes into long, thin strings that are each about ⁄3 inch (0.8 cm) thick. Rinse the potatoes a bit after you cut them to cut down on the starchiness. To soften up the potatoes, you can boil a pot of water and blanch them for 4 minutes first, but this is not necessary. If you can handle it, of course, you can prepare the gravy at the same time as you prepare the potatoes. You just have to be very vigilant. Heat the oil. Pour the vegetable oil onto a saucepan and heat it up under medium high heat. Then, add the cut potatoes and cook them until they are golden brown. Add the gravy to the potatoes. Place the cooked potatoes on a paper towel to drain some of the oil and then add the gravy and one bag of cheese curds. Serve. Enjoy this dish on its own while it's hot.
